column4: I am a programmer; where do I start to start programming in Linux?
what sort of languages do you prefer?
gcc and g++ will be your main staples.

those are the standard C and C++ libraries. further library documentation is usually attached to whichever library packages you choose to install. also, consider installing the manpages-dev package. you're familiar with man pages?
you were on windows before, or?
process is nearly identical. install an ide if you want, but easiest just to whip up a text file in your favourite editor, and practice compiling a few "Hello, World!" analogues via the terminal.
google around for "subversion cvs howto" and the like. there is an enormous amount of material available for first-time users.
the web page referenced in the error message seems to have a solution for you.
Solution does not work; i've tried.
which did you try?
you've made ntfs-3g suid root?
yes
and you've verified that you have correct permissions on the mount point?
only other thing i can think of is the version of ntfs-3g. i assume you've checked that it is at least as recent as the version mentioned on the web page?

and if you replace "users" with just "user" in fstab?

well, if you've checked permissions and everything else, i don't know what else to suggest. consider having a look at the ntfs-3g forums, perhaps someone else has a similar issue.

no, the next mount command will check against the updated file.
